Situation1: The cleaner is checking the inventory of cleaning supplies during a routine clean.
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They notice someone in their circle going through difficulties and respond with care
Story:
As I moved from room to room, ticking off items on my cleaning checklist, I paused at the supply closet. The shelves were running low—barely enough detergent and sponges to last the week. My supervisor had made it clear: no supplies, no cleaning, and no cleaning meant trouble for me. I felt the pressure to keep everything stocked and organized, to make sure the household ran smoothly.

Just then, my phone buzzed. A message from Maria, a friend from church, flashed on the screen. She’d lost her job and was struggling to make ends meet. She asked if I had any extra cleaning supplies she could borrow, just until she got back on her feet. My heart ached for her. As a Christian, I knew I was called to show love and kindness, to help those in need, just as Jesus taught. But if I gave her what she needed, I’d be short on supplies for work, risking my job and disappointing my employer. I stood in the supply closet, torn between my duty as a cleaner and my calling as a Christian, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me.
